title: COMMENT | Ulu Tiram  terrorist  attack and national security
message:
COMMENT | I am deeply perplexed as an ordinary citizen of our beloved nation regarding the communication strategies employed by our leaders in addressing national security concerns.
I firmly believe that the Ulu Tiram attack should unequivocally be classified as a terrorist attack.
Whether the perpetrator acted alone or had familial ties to Jemaah Islamiyah is inconsequential.
Moreover, an assault on the police officers and the station should be seen as an assault on the sovereignty of our country and the Yang di-Pertuan Agong.
The planning and execution of the attack possess the characteristics commonly associated with terrorist attacks, as acknowledged by experts in the field of terrorism...

title: Man convicted of murder in Vancouver cop death
message:
VANCOUVER Wash. (KPTV) - A man has been found guilty Friday of multiple murder charges after he was accused of causing the death of an off-duty Vancouver police officer.
Julio Segura of Yakima has been found guilty of first-degree murder, second-degree murder, possession of a stolen car, first-degree robbery, and attempting to elude a police car.
He was found not guilty of first-degree attempted murder, second-degree attempted murder, first-degree attempted kidnapping, and first-degree burglary.
Judge Retsinas agreed with the defense’s contention that there’s no evidence to support two of the felony murder charges.
SEE ALSO:A Clark County judge dismissed two of three murder charges against a Yakima man on trial for the death of an off-duty Vancouver officer on Thursday.

title: Israel defiant after World Court ruling on Gaza , vows to continue fighting
message:
JERUSALEM — Israeli ministers dismissed on May 24's ruling by the International Court of Justice ordering Israel to cease its military operation in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, vowing to continue fighting to free its hostages and defeat Hamas.
The ruling by the World Court on May 24 was the latest in a series of steps in recent weeks that have deepened Israel's international isolation over its conduct of the war in Gaza, which has killed more than 35,000 Palestinians, according to local health authorities.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office rejected the allegations in the case brought by South Africa that Israel was carrying out genocide in Gaza as "false, outrageous and morally repugnant".
"The State of Israel is committed to continue fighting to return its hostages and promise the security of its citizens — wherever and whenever necessary — including in Rafah," he said in a statement.
ALSO READ: World Court to rule on request to halt Israel's Rafah offensive
event_breakdown: Israeli ministers dismiss World Court ruling on Gaza operation

title: Iraq 2003 and Gaza 2023
message:
Journalists looking to make one point or another about the 2023 Hamas war have often contrasted the fighting in Gaza with U.S. combat in Iraq.
More often than not, the point being made — at least in our largest and most influential news outlets — has been that the Gaza war is without parallel.
Doing so belies the newspaper’s claims that the rate of civilian deaths in Gaza compares unfavorably to the period of heavy bombardment in the 2003 Iraq war.
In this invasion period, civilian casualties in Iraq were likely higher than those casualties in Gaza.
Less surprising is the divergence in total numbers of casualties, as the Gaza war drags on without a clear victory.
event_breakdown:
- 2003 Iraq war, with heavy bombardment causing more civilian casualties
- 2023 Hamas war in Gaza, with likely civilian casualties in Gaza
- Gaza war drags on without clear victory, no comparison to Iraq invasion period

title: Deputy commander of Hamas killed in airstrike , says IDF
message:
Tel Aviv: A Deputy Commander of Hamas has been killed in an airstrike in the central Gaza Strip, the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) have announced.
The IDF in a statement on Friday night identified the killed Hamas commander as Tziad al-Din al-Sharfa.
The Israeli Army said the assassination of the senior Hamas leader was conducted through a joint operation between IDF, Shin Bet and Military Intelligence.
The IDF is now specifically focusing on senior leaders of Hamas and is working on specific inputs from Shin Bet and Israel Military intelligence on the movement of senior Hamas group leaders.
The Israeli Army in the statement said that he was killed a few days ago after receiving inputs from the internal security agency, Shin Bet.

title: More than two years on , KU suicide attack perpetrators still at large
message:
More than two years after the deadly suicide attack targeting Chinese nationals at the gate of Karachi University, police have failed to make any arrests even though the banned Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) had claimed responsibility for the attack.
An anti-terrorism court has already issued non-bailable arrest warrants for five fugitive BLA terrorists in connection with the April 2022 attack, which killed four people, including three Chinese nationals.
While expressing dissatisfaction over the failure to execute the arrest warrants for the five BLA fugitives, the court reissued non-bailable warrants for their arrest.
The fugitives include BLA Commander Bashir, Captain Rehman Gul, Khalil Ahmed Musa, alias Waja, Mir Safir Ahmed, and Bashir Zeib.
The victims of the suicide attack were identified as Huang Guiping, Director of the Confucius Institute at the University of Karachi, Ding Moping, Chen Sai, and Khalid, the driver.

Security events:

1. April 26, 2022: Suicide attack targeting Chinese nationals at the gate of Karachi University.

title: Israel strikes Rafah after top UN court orders it to halt offensive
message:
RAFAH: Israel bombed the Gaza Strip, including Rafah, on Saturday (May 25), a day after the top UN court ordered it to halt military operations in the southern city as efforts get underway in Paris to seek a ceasefire in the war sparked by Hamas' Oct 7 attack.
The International Court of Justice (ICJ) also demanded the immediate release of all hostages still held by Palestinian militants, hours after the Israeli military announced troops had recovered the bodies of three more of the captives from northern Gaza.
The Hague-based court, whose orders are legally binding but lack direct enforcement mechanisms, also ordered Israel to keep open the Rafah crossing between Egypt and Gaza, which it closed earlier this month at the start of its assault on the city.
Israel gave no indication it was preparing to change course in Rafah, insisting that the court had got it wrong.
The Palestinian militant group Hamas, which has ruled Gaza since 2007, welcomed the ICJ ruling on Rafah but criticised its decision to exclude the rest of war-torn Gaza from the order.
event_breakdown: Israel bombing Gaza, including Rafah, and the International Court of Justice ordering Israel to halt military operations in Rafah, but excluding the rest of Gaza.

The Britain-based watchdog group said that two Hezbollah members were killed, and several others, whose nationalities remained unknown, were injured in the attack.
The Observatory's data showed that these strikes have killed 141 military personnel and injured 57 others.

title: Pakistan to compensate families of slain Chinese workers

In a visit to Dasu, days after the attack, Pakistani Prime Minister Shahbaz Sharif vowed "fool-proof" security arrangements in a meeting with Chinese workers at the hydropower project.
A special military unit as well as local law enforcement are already responsible for the security of Chinese nationals in Pakistan.
In 2021, an attack on a bus carrying workers to the same hydropower project killed 13 people including at least nine Chinese nationals.

title: Life , Death , And A Dilemma On Ukraine New Front Line : Stay Or Go
message:
KOZACHA LOPAN, Ukraine – A three-kilometer shell shot from the Russian border, the boom of artillery fire rumbled over the village of Kozacha Lopan from both north and south every 10 minutes or less on a day in mid-May.
Tetyana has lived in Kozacha Lopan her whole life.
Now, signs all over town offer evacuation at no cost -- but she, her 93-year-old husband, and their daughter, Natasha, don’t want to leave.
Many of their neighbors, as well as people from other villages in the Kharkiv region, have been squeezed out by the Russian advance.
Back in Kozacha Lopan, there’s something else that makes Natasha reluctant to leave: her own pets and the strays she takes care of.
event_breakdown:
* Russian border is shelling Kozacha Lopan every 10 minutes on a day in mid-May from the north and south (3 km)
* Locals are offered evacuation with the support of the government, but few people left the village so far.
* In the middle of the text there's a map of Kozacha Lopan, in the report of the government as a potential dangerous area (crises, and education).
* Terrorists from Sakha region (Russia) tried to occupy the Pliomorets school in this town. 
* Terrorists seized media company in yavashytsia for info war reasons.
* Terrorists destroyed all bus stations in yavashytsia quite early in the war.

title: Ukraine gain control in Kharkiv border areas : Zelenskiy
message:
Kharkiv is about 20 km from the Russian border.
Moscow's troops have in recent weeks captured villages in the area as part of a broad push, and analysts say they may be trying to get within artillery range of the city.
Ukrainian authorities have evacuated more than 11,000 people from the region since the start of the offensive on May 10.

message:
Kharkiv regional governor Oleg Synegubov said "unfortunately there are already four dead" and "38 wounded" after two guided Russian bombs hit the store.
Two of those killed "were men who worked in the hypermarket," Synegubov said earlier in a video posted on Telegram.
The latest attacks came after Russia launched a ground offensive in the Kharkiv region on May 10.
Russia said that Ukraine shelled a small town in the Belgorod border region, killing two people and wounding 10.
Ukraine said Russia shelled the village of Kupiansk-Vuzlovyi, a railway hub in the Kharkiv region near the border, wounding five, the regional prosecutor's office said.

title: Police urged to investigate former IRA commander who confessed to assassinating King Charles great uncle , Lord Mountbatten
message:
Police last night faced mounting pressure to investigate a former IRA commander who confessed to The Mail on Sunday that he was behind the assassination of King Charles's great uncle.
Michael Hayes callously boasted to this newspaper that he designed the bomb that killed Lord Mountbatten and masterminded the 1979 atrocity in Sligo, Ireland.
But, despite his comments this month, the Irish police have refused to say whether they intend to investigate him.
Lord Mountbatten was murdered aged 79 when the IRA blew up his fishing boat during a holiday at his summer home in Mullaghmore, Sligo.
Speaking to the MoS at his home in Dublin, Hayes bragged: 'I blew up Earl Mountbatten', adding: 'Yes, I blew him up.
event_breakdown:
Event 1: The Mail on Sunday interviews an IRA commander who confessed to the assassination of Prince Charles's great uncle, Lord Mountbatten
Event 2: The IRA commander admits to designing the bomb and masterminding the 1979 atrocity in Sligo, Ireland
Event 3: Despite confessing to the murder, the Irish police have refused to say whether they intend to investigate the former IRA commander

title: Israel Pursues Rafah Offensive Despite UN Court Ruling
message:
TEL AVIV — Israel’s armed forces were active in the southernmost city of the Gaza Strip on Saturday, despite a call by the International Court of Justice (ICJ) for an immediate end to the military operation in Rafah.
Israeli soldiers killed several Palestinian gunmen who had previously fired at the Israelis, the army said.
The Palestinian news agency Wafa reported that one civilian was killed in an Israeli airstrike in the city, which borders Egypt.
On Friday, the ICJ ordered Israel to immediately end the military operation in Rafah, as part of a case brought by South Africa.
According to the army, Israeli soldiers killed dozens of enemy fighters in the last 24 hours, partly in close combat and partly through targeted airstrikes.
event_breakdown:
Event 1: Israeli soldiers killed several Palestinian gunmen. The Palestinian news agency Wafa reported that one civilian was killed in an Israeli airstrike in Rafah.
Event 2: Despite a call by the International Court of Justice for an immediate end to the military operation in Rafah, Israel’s armed forces were active in the southernmost city of the Gaza Strip on Saturday.
Event 3: The army said Israeli soldiers killed dozens of enemy fighters in the Gaza Strip in the last 24 hours, partly in close combat and partly through targeted airstrikes.

title: Uvalde families sue Meta and Call of Duty maker on second anniversary of school attack
message:
The lawsuit against Georgia-based gun-maker Daniel Defense was filed in Texas by the same group of 19 families who sued on Wednesday.
The lawsuit against Meta and Activision Blizzard — the maker of Call of Duty — were filed in California with additional families of victims from the attack.
Daniel Defense and Meta each did not immediately respond to emails requesting comment.
In a congressional hearing in 2022, Daniel Defense CEO Marty Daniels called the Uvalde shooting and others like it "pure evil" and "deeply disturbing."
At least two other lawsuits have been filed against Daniel Defense.
event_breakdown:
.
* A lawsuit against a Georgia-based gun-maker, Daniel Defense, was filed in Texas by a group of 19 families who sued on Wednesday.
* Another lawsuit against Meta and Activision Blizzard - the maker of Call of Duty - was filed in California with additional families of victims from the Uvalde school shooting.
* The CEO of Daniel Defense described Uvalde and other schools shootings as "pure evil" and "deeply disturbing" in a 2022 congressional hearing.

Bombing a construction hypermarket in Kharkiv on a Saturday is one additional evidence of the brutal and criminal character of Russia’s leadership.

title: Infinite Unknown – Page 4056 – The man who trades freedom for security does not deserve nor will he ever receive either . – Benjamin Franklin
message:
The FBI views Ardito as one of the most powerful men in the Genovese family, a major part of the national Mafia.
The surveillance technique came to light in an opinion published this week by U.S. District Judge Lewis Kaplan.
He ruled that the “roving bug” was legal because federal wiretapping law is broad enough to permit eavesdropping even of conversations that take place near a suspect’s cell phone.
“They can be remotely accessed and made to transmit room audio all the time,” he said.
“You can do that without having physical access to the phone.”Read moreFBI Taps Cell Phone Microphone As Surveillance Tool

Some security events in the text are:
1. The FBI views Ardito as one of the most powerful men in the Genovese family, a major part of the national Mafia.
2. The wiretapping technique came to light in an opinion published this week by U.S. District Judge Lewis Kaplan.
3. He ruled that the “roving bug” was legal because federal wiretapping law is broad enough to permit eavesdropping even of conversations that take place near a suspect’s cell phone.
4. The FBI can remotely access a cell phone microphone and make it transmit room audio all the time, without having physical access to the phone.
Note that some events are related, and therefore are listed as a single event in brief.

title: Russians conduct around 100 offensive and assault operations on 25 May – General Staff
message:
Russian troops carried out 99 offensive and assault operations on Saturday 25 May.
Meanwhile, the Ukrainian Defence Forces are taking all necessary measures to deplete the offensive potential of Russian troops, fighting the enemy and destroying their equipment."
Six Russian attacks have been successfully repelled by Ukrainian soldiers, four are still ongoing.
Half of them were successfully repelled by Ukraine's Defence Forces, and seven are still ongoing.
On the Orikhiv front, the Russians attempted three assault attacks near Robotyne and Novoandriivka, but failed.
event_breakdown:
.
* Russian troops carried out 99 offensive and assault operations on Saturday 25 May.
* Ukrainian Defence Forces successfully repelled six Russian attacks, four are currently ongoing.
* Russia attempted three assault attacks near Orikhiv but failed.

title: Russian attacks on DIY store , city centre in Ukraine Kharkiv kill six , injure dozens
message:
Kharkiv Mayor Ihor Terekhov said about 120 people had been in the hardware store when the bombs struck.
"The attack targeted the shopping centre, where there were many people - this is clearly terrorism," Terekhov said.
The past week has seen an uptick in strikes on the city after Russian troops stormed across the border, opening a new front north of the city.
Russia has bombarded Kharkiv, which lies about 30 kilometres (20 miles) from its border, throughout the war, having reached its outskirts in a failed bid to capture it in 2022.
event_breakdown:
1. Russian troops stormed across the border and opened a new front north of the city.
2. Russian troops tried to capture the city of Kharkiv in 2022, but were stopped by Ukrainian troops.
3. Russian troops have reached the outskirts of Kharkiv and bombarded the city throughout the war.
4. Russian troops shelled the city, leaving two dead and edging closer to the centre of eastern Ukraine's second city.
5. Russian troops bomb attacked Kharkiv and a shopping center, and the Mayor says it's clearly terrorism.

Russian forces struck a Ukrainian shopping center in Kharkiv on Saturday, leaving four people dead and 38 people wounded according to local officials.
